citations.narrative:
The facility is storing food in a way that does not prevent contamination and is not stored off the floor. There are two bags
of open food for the pheasants and ducks stored on the floor, the open bag of scratch grains had an accumulation of live
moths inside the bag. Additionally, a set of velvet deer antlers were found in the animal food freezer. Food that is not
stored in a way to prevent contamination from insect pests or other animal parts not intended for food may lead to a risk of
disease hazards to the animals.
Supplies of food, including food supplements, bedding, and substrate must be stored in a manner that protects the
supplies from deterioration, spoilage (harmful microbial growth), contamination, and vermin infestation. The supplies must
be stored off the floor and away from the walls, to allow cleaning underneath and around the supplies. All food must be
stored in a manner that prevents deterioration of its nutritive value. Animal waste and dead animals and animal parts not
intended for food must not be kept in food storage or food preparation areas, food freezers, food refrigerators, and animal
areas.
Correct by: 22-September-2023

An enclosure housing 10 ducks of various species had multiple sharp wire points along the fence line at the height
accessible by the ducks and a piece of hardware cloth with sharp points was present on the ground under a shelter
structure. Sharp points may cause injury and may lead to pain or discomfort to the animals. Primary enclosures must be
designed and constructed of suitable materials so that they are structurally sound. The primary enclosures must be kept
in good repair and have no sharp points or edges that could injure the birds.
Correct by: 15-September-2023

There were exposed light bulb sockets within the sheltered side of three mew enclosures for the red-tailed hawk, great
horned owl and a turkey vulture. The facility representative was unsure if the sockets had electrical current going to them
at the time of inspection. Exposed electrical outlets may cause injury and may lead to pain or discomfort to the animals.
Primary enclosures must be designed and constructed of suitable materials so that they are structurally sound. The
primary enclosures must be kept in good repair and protect the birds from injury.
Correct by: 22-September-2023

The perch for one great horned owl is in disrepair. It is a wood perch that is wrapped in layers of rope, tape and medical
bandage tape. The layers are worn with holes in the tape and tattered rope present as well. Perches and other furniture-
type objects not kept in good repair present a risk of injury to the birds if they were to get tangled in the tattered rope.
Furniture-type objects, such as perches and other objects that enrich a bird's environment, must be species-appropriate
and be designed, constructed, and maintained so as to prevent harm to the bird.
Correct by: 22-September-2023

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility does not have a written environment enhancement plan for birds at the time of inspection. The attending
veterinarian has been unavailable to sign paperwork but is available in the next week or two to do the facility visit and sign
paperwork. An appointment has not been made at the time of inspection. When the inspector asked to see a draft of the
enrichment plan, a draft was not available. Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow
a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The
plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian and must be in accordance with the regulations in this subpart and
with currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference guides. This plan
must be made available to APHIS upon request. Correct by: 22-September-2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.150(e) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The facility is storing food in a way that does not prevent contamination and is not stored off the floor. There are two bags 
of open food for the pheasants and ducks stored on the floor, the open bag of scratch grains had an accumulation of live 
moths inside the bag. Additionally, a set of velvet deer antlers were found in the animal food freezer. Food that is not 
stored in a way to prevent contamination from insect pests or other animal parts not intended for food may lead to a risk of 
disease hazards to the animals.  
Supplies of food, including food supplements, bedding, and substrate must be stored in a manner that protects the 
supplies from deterioration, spoilage (harmful microbial growth), contamination, and vermin infestation. The supplies must 
be stored off the floor and away from the walls, to allow cleaning underneath and around the supplies. All food must be 
stored in a manner that prevents deterioration of its nutritive value. Animal waste and dead animals and animal parts not 
intended for food must not be kept in food storage or food preparation areas, food freezers, food refrigerators, and animal 
areas.  
Correct by: 22-September-2023 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
An enclosure housing 10 ducks of various species had multiple sharp wire points along the fence line at the height

3.153(a)(1)(ii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
There were exposed light bulb sockets within the sheltered side of three mew enclosures for the red-tailed hawk, great 
horned owl and a turkey vulture. The facility representative was unsure if the sockets had electrical current going to them

Primary enclosures must be designed and constructed of suitable materials so that they are structurally sound. The

primary enclosures must be kept in good repair and protect the birds from injury. 
Correct by: 22-September-2023 
3.153(a)(2) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The perch for one great horned owl is in disrepair. It is a wood perch that is wrapped in layers of rope, tape and medical 
bandage tape. The layers are worn with holes in the tape and tattered rope present as well. Perches and other furniture-
type objects not kept in good repair present a risk of injury to the birds if they were to get tangled in the tattered rope. 
Furniture-type objects, such as perches and other objects that enrich a bird's environment, must be species-appropriate 
and be designed, constructed, and maintained so as to prevent harm to the bird.  
Correct by: 22-September-2023 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility does not have a written environment enhancement plan for birds at the time of inspection. The attending 
veterinarian has been unavailable to sign paperwork but is available in the next week or two to do the facility visit and sign 
paperwork. An appointment has not been made at the time of inspection. When the inspector asked to see a draft of the 
enrichment plan, a draft was not available. Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow 
a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The 
plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian and must be in accordance with the regulations in this subpart and 
with currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference guides. This plan 
must be made available to APHIS upon request. Correct by: 22-September-2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.

species.common: RED FOX (INCLUDES SILVER FOX & CROSS FOX)
